PassiveRecord

An simple implementation of the Mozilla SQLite Storage API wrapped in an ActiveRecord ‘like’ API.  The functions are specially tuned for the needs of PMOG, hence the Passive in PassiveRecord.

Summary
PassiveRecord
An simple implementation of the Mozilla SQLite Storage API wrapped in an ActiveRecord ‘like’ API.
Functions
PassiveRecord
Initializes the Object
find
Basic Find statement using attributes provided
create
Insert a new record into the database.
update
Update records matching the attributes condition param
destroy
Delete a record in the database
validate
Validates the record using validates defined in the schema for the table in question
validate_uniqueness_of
Ensure that only one record appears in a specific table using a specific column
bootstrap
Load the schema file into the db
Constants
Schema
This constant is meant to emulate the schema file found in most rails application.

Functions

PassiveRecord

function PassiveRecord(db_name)

Initializes the Object

Parameters

db_nameThe name of the database to find or create

find

PassiveRecord.prototype.find = function(table,
params)

Basic Find statement using attributes provided

Parameters

tablestring of the table to search
paramshash or attributes to use as conditions within the search

Returns: An Array of hashes corresponding to the records in the database that matched the search query.

Example Usage

records = this.find(‘players’, { conditions : [‘`login` = ? AND `id` = ? AND `armored` = ?’, ‘heavysixer’, 1, true], limit : 1}) records # => [{ login : ‘heavysixer’, email : ‘f.nosp@m.oo@bar.nosp@m..com’ ... id : 1}]

create

PassiveRecord.prototype.create = function(table,
params)

Insert a new record into the database.

Parameters

tablestring of the table to update
paramshash of attributes to insert in the table

Example Usage

var player = { attributes : {“armor”:391,”datapoints”:2275,”secondary_association”:”Bedouin”,”st_nicks”:119,”login”:”heavysixer”,”tertiary_association”:”Pathmaker”,”level”:14,”mines”:0,”next_level”:15,”user_id”:”91dc43e4-946f-11dc-a79b-00163e4ab66d”,”level_percentage”:98,”avatar_mini”:”/system/image_assets/0000/0000/0000/8932/mark_elliott_IR_mini.jpg”,”armored”:true,”lightposts”:98,”crates”:346,”skin”:”classic”,”primary_association”:”Seer”} } this.create(‘players’, player)

update

PassiveRecord.prototype.update = function(table,
params)

Update records matching the attributes condition param

destroy

PassiveRecord.prototype.destroy = function(table,
params)

Delete a record in the database

Parameters

tablestring of the table to update
paramshash of attributes to use to find the record.

Example Usage

this.result = this.db.destroy(‘whitelists’, { conditions: [“`id` = ? “, id] })

validate

PassiveRecord.prototype.validate = function(table,
params)

Validates the record using validates defined in the schema for the table in question

Parameters

tablestring of the table to consult for validations
paramshash of attributes to validate

validate_uniqueness_of

PassiveRecord.prototype.validate_uniqueness_of = function(table,
validation,
params)

Ensure that only one record appears in a specific table using a specific column

Parameters

tablestring of the table to consult for validations
validationhash of params that define how the validation is to be run.
paramshash of attributes to validate

Returns

A hash containing errors for the validation if there are any.

bootstrap

PassiveRecord.prototype.bootstrap = function(param)

Load the schema file into the db

Parameters

paramboolean if true then existing tables are dropped and recreated.

Example Usage

this.bootstrap(true); // This will destroy the existing tables and recreate them this.bootstrap(); // will only create the table if it doesn’t already exist.

Constants

Schema

This constant is meant to emulate the schema file found in most rails application.  The typical location of this file is db/config/schema

Also like ActiveRecord the id field is automatically added to each table as the unique auto-incrementing index.
